”This study marks the first time that a person living with paralysis has regained movement by using signals recorded from within the brain,” said bioelectronic medicine researcher Chad Bouton of the New   Feinstein Institute for Medical Research, who worked on the study at the Battelle Memorial Institute in Ohio.

Burkhart first demonstrated the ”neural bypass” technology in 2014 when he was able simply to open and close his hand.
On June 13th, 2010, college freshman Ian Burkhart was goofing off in the ocean with his friends, when he dove into the wrong wave.
It was the summer after his freshman year of college when Burkhart lost the ability to move his arms and legs.
Burkhart, a former lacrosse goalie, suffered a broken neck and spinal cord damage at age 19 diving into a wave at North Carolina’s Outer Banks in 2010, causing paralysis of his arms and legs.
The electrodes on Burkhart’s arm then recreated those movements by stimulating his muscles in preset sequences.
Electrical stimulation from those electrodes activates his hand and finger muscles.

“Not only were we able to find those signals in the brain and decipher them for individual finger movements, but we were able to link those signals to Ian’s muscles and allow that kind of movement to be regained.
Now “it’s gotten much easier,” he said in an interview.
But with more and more practise it became much easier.
“Surprisingly, it worked pretty much right away,” says Burkhart.
From the start, he was hopeful that advances in medical technology would improve his quality of life.

“I mentioned that I was interested in taking part in research because I knew that with the way science and technology were progressing, something would come along during my lifetime that would improve my quality of life,” he says.
“I was 19 years old, really independent, and I didn’t think anything like this would happen in my life that would slow me down and set me back this much,” Burkhart said during a press briefing.
”Things are kind of moving along better than I imagined,” Burkhart said.
There are a lot of risks,” said Burkhart.

When Burkhart is in the lab, a cable is attached to a small projection from his skull to carry signals from the sensor to a computer, which interprets what movement he is trying to accomplish.

The study builds on previous work in which humans have been able to move computer cursors and robotic arms using their own brain signals, and a study in which monkeys with paralysed arms were able to move them again thanks to a similar intervention.

He has some residual movement in his shoulders, and can use those working shoulder muscles to move his arms about.
Burkhart had therapy for the injury with a team of doctors at Ohio State University.
After his condition stabilized, Burkhart moved back home with his family in Columbus, Ohio and started doing rehabilitation therapy at Ohio State University.
Details of the system that allows him to do this, developed by scientists at Ohio State University and Battelle Memorial Institute, are published in the journal Nature today.
And yet, in those few hours, Burkhart could move his   hand, rotate his wrist, and pinch his fingers.
Burkhart’s thoughts and brain signals work in the same way as they did before the accident, but his spinal cord injury means they never reach his hand, leaving him unable to move it.

An Ohio man paralyzed in an accident while diving in waves can now pick up a bottle or play the video game Guitar Hero thanks to a small computer chip in his brain that lets his mind guide his hands and fingers, bypassing his damaged spinal cord.
What muscles do I use?” Bouton’s team used   algorithms to decode the patterns of brain activity that signified each movement.
Burkhart watches videos of different hand movements he’s going to perform that day and thinks about the movements, so the computer learns what the brain signals for each movement looks like.
The patterns of the signals are tuned to produce the movements Burkhart thinks about making.
The technology potentially could help people not only after spinal cord injuries but after strokes or traumatic brain injuries, Bouton added.

“We think this is an important result as we try and pave the way for other patients in the future, not only those with spinal injuries, but also those that have experienced a stroke, and potentially even traumatic brain injury,” he said.
In Burkhart’s case, “we not only decoded brain activity in the motor area of someone who’s paralyzed, but we also linked those signals back to their body,” says Bouton.
But the brain implant approach could be useful for people with more severe injuries who can’t control those other muscles, or who need a more complex signal to make particular movements, he said.
Burkhart performed the first movements using thoughts alone in 2014, but has since learned more complex actions and more precise control over his hand and fingers.
“But just like anything, with more and more practice it’s become easier.

But he can do these things only for a few hours a week, in a laboratory where he is hooked up to an experimental device that interprets his brain signals and stimulates his muscles with electrodes on his forearm.

Scientists on Wednesday described accomplishments achieved by    quadriplegic Ian Burkhart using an implanted chip that relays signals from his brain through 130 electrodes on his forearm to produce muscle movement in his hands and fingers.

A    man who was paralysed in an accident six years ago has regained some control of his hand using an implant that sends signals from his brain directly to the muscles that move his wrist and fingers.
Burkhart was a college freshman when he broke his neck about six years ago.
“Ten years ago we couldn’t do this.
The    from Dublin, Ohio, was in an accident six years ago that left his arms and legs paralysed.

Known as a neural bypass, the implant allows Ian Burkhart to swipe a credit card, play the video game, Guitar Hero, and perform actions such as picking up a bottle and pouring the contents, holding a phone to his ear, and stirring a cup.
He can grab a credit card and swipe it through a reader.

Burkhart, with six wrist and hand motions, could rotate his hand, make a fist, pinch his fingers together, grasp objects like a bottle, spoon and telephone, swipe a credit card and play the video game simulating guitar strumming.

But now, thanks to computer software that decodes his thoughts and sends the signal to his hands, he’s been able to pick up small objects, swipe a credit card, and even play Guitar Hero  —   albeit in a science lab.
“It was a flicker of hope, knowing that this was something that was working, knowing I will be able to use my hand again,” he said.
If and when the device can be used at home, “it will really increase my quality of life and independence,” said Burkhart, who is paralyzed over most of his body.

Right now, it’s only in a clinical setting, but with enough people working on it, and enough attention, it can be something I can use outside of the hospital, at my home and outside my home, and really improve the quality of my life,” he said.
Over the following months, he learned to move individual fingers.
He can move individual fingers and hold a toothbrush.
This is the first time a person with paralysis has regained movement in their hands and individual fingers using signals from their brain.
This signal is passed to a computer that decodes it, and the resulting instruction is then sent to a sleeve he wears on his forearm that stimulates the muscles that move his wrist and fingers.
The fuzz of brain activity is fed into a computer and converted into electrical pulses that bypass the injured spinal cord and connect to a sleeve that Burkhart wears on his forearm.
When Burkhart thought about moving his arm, the implant would decode the activity in his neurons and feed the signals to a sleeve of electrodes on his forearm.
The chip, connected to a cable running from his head to a sleeve containing the electrodes wrapped around his forearm, sends brain signals that stimulate muscles controlling the hands and fingers.
“This is taking one’s thoughts and, within milliseconds, linking it to concrete movements,” said Dr Ali Rezai, a study author and neurosurgeon at Ohio State University.
“It was an amazing moment for the team,” said Ali Rezai, a neurosurgeon at Ohio State’s Wexner Medical Center, recalling Burkhart’s first hand movements.
Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center neurosurgeon Ali Rezai called the results a ”milestone in the evolution of   interface technology”.
” Burkhart learned that a local team, led by engineer Chad Bouton and neurosurgeon Ali Rezai, were developing a technological bypass for injured spinal cords.
It would be four years before he moved his hand again.
In June 2014, in the early stages of the trial, Burkhart moved his hand again for the first time after his accident.
” “The first time I moved my hand, I had that flicker of hope knowing that this is something that’s working, I will be able to use my hand again.
Surgeons implanted the   chip into his motor cortex, which controls voluntary muscular activity.
Here, the chip picked up electrical signals from the part of the motor cortex that controls hand movements.
In April 2014, the team surgically implanted an array of microscopic electrodes in Burkhart’s motor cortex —  the part of the brain that governs his movements.

He couldn’t feel his arms or legs.
To test how useful this would be in a normal situation, the scientists had Burkhart pick up a container, empty its contents into a jar, then pick up a stick and stir the contents of the jar.
Ian Burkhart of Dublin, Ohio, can grasp a bottle, pour its contents into a jar, pick up a stick and stir the liquid.

He could even pick up a bottle, pour its contents into another jar, and stir it with a small stick —  a complicated sequence that involves two kinds of grasps (a   one, and a delicate pinch) and several coordinated movements of hand, wrist, and arm.
